task_description: Facing the building to your West (approx. 262°), estimate the height of the main building in front of you in meters. Answer with one number and a short rationale.

reason: To estimate the building's height, I need to see its full vertical extent; rotating the camera upward will reveal the roofline which is likely not visible at the current 0° pitch.
The current heading (0°N) no longer faces the target building; rotating left to 270° (west) will reorient toward the building to assess its full height.
To estimate the building's height, I need to see its full vertical profile; rotating upward to 30° pitch will reveal the roofline while maintaining alignment with the building at 270°W.
The current heading (0°N) is misaligned with the target building; rotating left 90° will reorient to 270°W to face the building while maintaining the upward pitch for height assessment.
To capture the building's full height, I need to tilt the camera upward while maintaining the westward heading to observe the roofline relative to the ground.
The current heading (0°N) is misaligned with the target building; rotating left 90° will face 270°W while maintaining the 30° upward pitch to observe the building's full height profile.
To capture the building's full height, I need to tilt the camera upward while maintaining the westward heading to observe the roofline relative to the ground.
The current heading (0°N) is misaligned with the target building; rotating left 90° will face 270°W while maintaining the 30° upward pitch to observe the building's full height profile.

The current heading (270°W) aligns with the target building; rotating upward to 30° pitch will reveal the roofline, enabling height estimation based on visible vertical extent and typical building proportions.
After multiple alignment attempts, the building's height can be estimated by observing its vertical extent at 30° upward pitch; typical 4-story structures suggest ~12 meters.
